document.docAuthor: Orr, Michael C., Pitts, James P. & Griswold, Terry
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the bee group Anthophora (Micranthophora) (Hymenoptera: Apidae), with notes on potential conservation concerns and a molecular phylogeny of the genus

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the bee group Anthophora (Micranthophora) (Hymenoptera: Apidae), with notes on potential conservation concerns and a molecular phylogeny of the genus

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Anthophora hololeuca Cockerell, 1923: 82
( holotype : ♀ ; Puerto Refugio, Angel de la Guardia Island, Gulf of California, Mexico ; coll. E.P. Van Duzee, 29 Jun. 1921 , at
Psorothamnus spinosus
; CASENT, type 941).

subSubSection.paragraph: Female similar to male, except: Head: Mandible with inferior tooth a very small but distinct nub, clearly angled off main blade ( Fig. 41A ). Mesosoma: Midtibial spur apically curved; tan to orange, uncommonly somewhat brown. Basitibial plate circular and sometimes elongate distally, usually teardropped overall. Metasoma: T1–T4 covered in appressed setae; T5 with extensive appressed setae. T4 impunctate rim of short length medially, usually not visible. Anal fimbria broadly triangular to relatively linear, covering fourth to third of T5 length medially. Pubescence: See Fig. 46A . Hindbasitarsal brush medium to dark brown; anal fimbria sometimes offwhite.

Distribution. See Fig. 18 . Present in USA : California Nevada , Arizona , Utah ; Mexico : Baja California Norte, Sonora , Baja California Sur . Found most commonly in Sonoran and Mojave Deserts, as well as Great Basin Desert. Ecoregional habitance is as follows, based on 1114 specimen records: 8 ecoregions total: Sonoran Desert (675=60.2%), Great Basin shrub steppe (256=22.8%), Mojave Desert (153=13.6%), Baja California desert (13=1.2%), Gulf of California xeric scrub (7≤1%), California montane chaparral and woodlands (5≤1%), Colorado Plateau shrublands (4≤1%), Sonoran-Sinaloan transition subtropical dry forest (1≤1%), NULL (6≤1%).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 18. Distribution of
Anthophora hololeuca
. Generated with 1114 specimen records from 254 locations.

subSubSection.paragraph: Phenology. Recorded from February–December, primarily spring, generally later at higher latitudes. Likely facultatively bivoltine.
Nesting biology. Unknown, potentially uses sand, given that several floral hosts are psammophytic.

Floral specialization. Reported as a specialist on
Dalea
and related genera ( Fabaceae ) ( Moldenke & Neff 1974 ). Almost certainly true, primarily on
Psorothamnus
and
Dalea
. Short, recurved galea appears well-suited to the small flowers of these plants. Hurd & Linsley (1975) incorrectly consider this species polylectic. Primary recorded visits by 257 females include: Family Fabaceae (93%); Genus
Psorothamnus
(57%),
Dalea
(34%); Species
Psorothamnus emoryi
(30%). 546 total floral records from 13 families include:
Asteraceae
( 12 ♂ 5 ♀ ):
Acamptopappus sphaerocephalus

Comments. A male of this species has been observed resting overnight on an unidentifiable dead plant via its mandible.
